title: Pilosa
text:
The order Pilosa is a <a href="clade">clade</a> of <a href="Xenarthra">xenarthran</a> <a href="placental">placental</a> <a href="mammal">mammal</a>s, native to the Americas. It includes the <a href="anteater">anteater</a>s and <a href="sloth">sloth</a>s, including the extinct <a href="ground%20sloth">ground sloth</a>s, which became extinct about 10,000 years ago. The name comes from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> word for "hairy".
Origins and taxonomy.
The <a href="Biogeography">biogeographic origins</a> of the Pilosa are still unclear, but they can be traced back in <a href="South%20America">South America</a> as far as the early <a href="Paleogene">Paleogene</a> (about 60 million years ago, only a short time after the end of the <a href="Mesozoic%20Era">Mesozoic Era</a>). The presence of these animals in <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> and their former presence in <a href="North%20America">North America</a> is a result of the <a href="Great%20American%20Interchange">Great American Interchange</a>. <a href="Pilosans%20of%20the%20Caribbean">A number of sloths</a> were also formerly present on the <a href="Greater%20Antilles">Antilles</a>, which they reached from South America by some combination of <a href="oceanic%20dispersal">rafting or floating</a> with the prevailing currents.
Together with the <a href="armadillo">armadillo</a>s, which are in the order Cingulata, pilosans are part of the larger superorder <a href="Xenarthra">Xenarthra</a>, a defining characteristic of which is the presence of xenarthrals (extra formations between <a href="lumbar%20vertebrae">lumbar vertebrae</a>). In the past, Pilosa was regarded as a suborder of the order Xenarthra, while some more recent classifications regard Pilosa as an order within the superorder Xenarthra. Earlier still, both armadillos and pilosans were classified together with <a href="pangolin">pangolin</a>s and the <a href="aardvark">aardvark</a> as the order <a href="Edentata">Edentata</a> (meaning toothless, because the members do not have front incisor teeth or molars, or have poorly developed molars). Edentata was subsequently realized to be <a href="polyphyletic">polyphyletic</a>; it contained unrelated families and was thus invalid.
